title: What is the difference between Broadband, Router and WiFi? - Quora

response.answer_text: Broadband is a high-capacity transmission technique used to send large quantities of data quickly. DSL, Cable, Fiber Optic, and Satellite are all considered Broadband Internet services. In layman’s terms, broadband is any Internet connection that’s faster than dial-up. A Router is a piece of hardware that routes data through your home network. The most common form of router looks something like this:  A small box with blinking lights and several various ports on the back for things like ethernet, a phone line (if you’re using DSL) or a coax jack (for cable internet), and most likely a USB port for things like printers or storage. If it’s also a Wireless Router, it’ll have antennas sticking out of it. Nowadays, Internet Service Providers will provide you with a modem that also has a router and Wi-Fi capabilities integrated all integrated into a single unit. Wi-Fi is a type of wireless communication technology that provides high speed Internet access to portable devices like laptops, smartphones, gaming systems, and so on.

*Broadband is a high speed Internet service, provided by Fibre, Hybrid Co-ax (Cable TV) or ADSL. It has a minimum speed of 512Kb/s but can be up to 500Mb/s or beyond (The UK is rolling out Gigabit). A Router is a device which connects networks. in corporations its a rack mountable box which can be configured by administrators to connect to the Internet or various parts of the networks and provide services as needed. The home router is a device, usually branded for the broadband supplier. It offers services to allow you to connect to the Internet (DNS, DHCP) and usually 4 network sockets to connect to the home network. It can also be a 3rd party device which you use to improve the functionality of your ISP router. Wifi is a wireless network usually in the 2.4GHz and 5GHz spectrum. It allows the Internet to be accessible by mobile phones, tablets and laptops, as well as other devices without plugging into a network port. Usually the wifi is provided as part of the broadband router but in other cases it can be its own separate system with one or more Access Points to improve coverage.
